abstract: New Jersey Supreme Court rules that part of state's bias-intimidation law, which says person can be charged with hate crime if victim believes they are being harassed for reasons of bias, is unconstitutionally vague; upholds other parts of law that say perpetrator must know harassment would cause offense; decision could affect case of Dharun Ravi, Rutgers student who was convicted of harassing homosexual roommate Tyler Clementi, who later committed suicide.
lead_paragraph: The State Supreme Court’s decision could affect the appeals in the prosecution of Dharun Ravi, who was convicted in 2012 of using a webcam to spy on his Rutgers roommate, Tyler Clementi.

headline.main: Part of New Jersey’s Bias-Intimidation Law Is Ruled Unconstitutional
headline.print_headline: Top New Jersey Court Rules Part of Bias Law Is Unconstitutional

snippet: The State Supreme Court’s decision could affect the appeals in the prosecution of Dharun Ravi, who was convicted in 2012 of using a webcam to spy on his Rutgers roommate, Tyler Clementi.
